Award.AwardTitle: MRI-Consortium: Development of the Forward Tagger for the CLAS12 Detector at Jefferson Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
This MRI grant will help support the development of a particle detector being built by an international collaboration of scientists. The primary objective for the experiment using this detector is the search for new and exotic forms of matter. Regular matter is made from protons, neutrons and electrons. Many other types of particles are known, but some short-lived particles are predicted to exist from theoretical models of the theory of the strong force, called quantum chromodynamics (QCD). When high-energy photons strike a proton target, many particles are produced, and some of these may be the predicted exotic particles such as glueballs or hybrid mesons.

In the process of developing this instrumentation, physicists train students in the use of high-technology equipment and electronics. Some of these students go on to develop new uses of the technology, such as the diagnostic equipment used in many hospitals, including MRI, CAT and PET scanners. The economic impact of a highly-trained workforce is well-documented. The development of this equipment will train students with high technology skills that are needed in today's marketplace, while adding to our understanding of QCD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The forward tagger is an instrument specifically designed to enhance the capabilities of the CLAS12 detector.  This detector is located in an experimental hall, HallB, at Jefferson laboratory in Newport News VA.  This facility, CEBAF at Jefferson lab, provides a focused beam of high energy electrons. The electron beam impinges on a target (.e.g. hydrogen) at the center of the CLAS12 detector system.  The collisions between electrons in the beam and the protons at the center of the hydrogen atom provides a way to study the proton. There are a host of targets and proposed studies approved.  The debri, various particles resulting from the collison, is measured by the CLAS12 detector. The resulting information is analyzed in order to study the structure and behavior of particles such as the proton.  The goal of these studies is to improve our understanding of the fundamental ingedients that govern nature. The fruits of such studies are an ever improving understanding of our world and advancements in technology due to the significant challenges of the research.

Details of the CLAS12 detector can be found at https://www.jlab.org/Hall-B/clas12-web/. The Forward Tagger, FT, is depcicted in the first few attached images. It is one of the specialized element of the CLAS12 detector that heightens sensitivity to processes that probe interesting aspects under investigation. The FT  consists of three basic elements: tracker, hodoscope, and calorimeter. These three elements sit very close to the beam and will enable the detection of processes where and electron is scattered through small angles. These events are essential for probing quasi real photon scattering. These events are expected to provide higher yields of hybrid mesons. As stated above certain processes are expected to be useful in untangling the fundamental nature of these processes. The production of mesons by electrons at glancing collsions is one such process. The Technical Design Report as well as this MRI proposal provide more specific details as to the importance of this detector and the reasons these specific scattering events are interesting.

The current status of the design, construction and testing of the Forward Tagger is that all three elements are now entering the final testing phase.  The calorimeter and hodoscope will be setup in a testing area at Jefferson lab so that these two elements can be configured and completely tested over the next 6 months. The trackker is expected to arrive in January 2016 and will be added to the test setup. 

The developments necessary to complete the design and the constructionof the detectors were challenging and the realization of the three pieces in their final from is a major success.  The expectation is the final assmbly of the complete Forward tagger should be straightforward and the installation of this package as part of CLAS12 should be accomplished without difficulties.

While the final success will be demonstrated when experiments at Jefferson Lab are completed and analyzed, the successful construction of the Forward Tagger is a major milestone and represents the planned successful outcome for this MRI.

In addition, the James Madison University Particle amd Nuclear physics group will remain engaged in using the Forward Tagger to enhance the studies of interest.
